units.title: Tissue Collection and Storage
units.text: Collect primary human tissue pieces, separated by biopsy site and/or tissue type (i.e., normal and tumor tissue) in 45 ml of ice-cold adDMEM/F12+++ medium in 50-ml conical tubes. (Optional) Add 10 µM ROCK inhibitor to adDMEM/F12+++ medium to increase cell survival. Keep tissue samples in this medium at 4 °C until the start of the isolation.
units.rationale: This is an actionable step for preparing primary tissue for organoid culture with specific conditions for preservation.

units.title: Removal of Non-Epithelial Tissue
units.text: Assess whether obtained tissue pieces consist purely of epithelium or if they also contain fat or muscle tissue. If so, remove non-epithelial components as much as possible using surgical scissors or scalpels and forceps under a dissection microscope. If not, continue to the next step immediately.
units.rationale: This step is critical for ensuring purity of epithelial cells prior to digestion and organoid formation.

units.title: Tissue Fragmentation
units.text: Mince the tissue into small fragments of 1–3 mm3 in a 10-cm cell culture dish using surgical scissors or scalpels.
units.rationale: This is a precise, actionable procedure to prepare tissue for enzymatic digestion.

units.title: Enzymatic Digestion
units.text: Digest the tissue (from Step 3) as appropriate based on the tumor type (Table 1). Carefully monitor digestion, and for <2-h incubations, mix contents every 10–15 min by shaking vigorously and by pipetting the mixture up and down using a P1000 pipette. For overnight incubations, place the mixture on a shaker.
units.rationale: This step details a controlled enzymatic digestion protocol with specific monitoring instructions.

units.title: Cell Filtration and Centrifugation
units.text: Wash once by topping up with 10 ml of adDMEM/F12+++ medium, and centrifuge at 200g for 5 min at 4 °C. Resuspend the pellet in 10 ml of adDMEM/F12+++ medium, and filter using a 100-µm cell strainer. Centrifuge the resuspended and ﬁltered cells at 200g for 5 min at 4 °C.
units.rationale: This sequence ensures removal of debris and isolation of viable cell suspensions for plating.

units.title: Plating in ECM Hydrogel
units.text: Aspirate the supernatant and resuspend the pellet in BME or Matrigel. BME should be kept on ice to prevent it from solidifying; thus, work quickly. The amount of BME depends on the size of the pellet. Approximately 10,000 cells should be plated in 40 µl of BME. Plate the BME containing organoids on the bottom of pre-heated 24-well suspension cell culture plates in drops of ~10 µl each. Place three to four drops into each well.
units.rationale: This is a detailed, step-by-step protocol for embedding cells in ECM hydrogel, critical for 3D organoid formation.

units.title: BME Solidification and Medium Addition
units.text: Place the culture plate into a humidiﬁed incubator at 37 °C and 5% (vol/vol) CO2 for 20–30 min to let the BME solidify. Once the BME drops are solidiﬁed (30–60 min), ﬂip the plate and carefully add 500 µl of organoid medium to each well.
units.rationale: This protocol ensures proper ECM gelation and avoids disruption of droplets during medium addition.

units.title: Organoid Medium Refreshment
units.text: Change the medium every 2–3 d by carefully aspirating medium from the wells and replacing it with fresh, pre-warmed medium. Keep ROCK inhibitor and Primocin (in the case of head and neck organoids, also caspofungin) in the culture medium for the ﬁrst two passages of the culture.
units.rationale: This specifies a routine maintenance step with critical reagent requirements for organoid survival.

units.title: Organoid Splitting via TrypLE
units.text: Pipette up and down to disrupt BME or Matrigel, and transfer the organoid suspension to a 15-ml conical tube. Resuspend the pellet in 1 ml of TrypLE, pipette up and down and incubate at 37 °C until organoids fall apart. Pipette up and down with a P1000 ﬁlter tip with a (non-ﬁltered) P10 tip on top for ≥10 times every 3–5 min to aid disruption of the organoids. Monitor digestion closely to keep the incubation time in TrypLE to a minimum.
units.rationale: This provides a precise enzymatic passaging protocol with timing and technique instructions.

units.title: Organoid Freezing
units.text: Add the required volume of cell-freezing medium, and pipette up and down using a P1000 pipette to properly resuspend the organoids. 500 μl of freezing medium should be used for four ‘original’ wells with organoids of a 24-well cell culture plate. Per sterile cryogenic vial, add 500 µl of freezing medium with the resuspended organoids. Place the cryogenic vial into a freezing container. Store the freezing container with the samples at –80 °C. After storage at –80 °C for 24 h, remove the vials from the freezing container, and transfer them to the liquid nitrogen tank (approximately –180 °C).
units.rationale: This is a standardized, actionable protocol for cryopreserving organoids with exact volumes and temperatures.
